result.reason: Folder disconnect only closes direct child connections, not connections in sub-folders — needs recursive traversal
result.approach: In DisconnectConnection(), when handling ContainerInfo, recursively traverse all descendant containers (not just direct children) to disconnect all connections. Use ContainerInfo.GetRecursiveChildList() or implement a recursive helper to find all ConnectionInfo descendants with open connections.

attempts.raw_output:
Now I can see the issue clearly. Looking at the `DisconnectConnection` method (line 898-908), when disconnecting a container (folder), it only iterates over `containerInfo.Children` — the **direct** children. It does NOT recurse into sub-folders. This is exactly what the issue reporter describes: disconnecting a folder only disconnects connections in that folder, not in sub-folders.

The fix is clear — the disconnect logic needs to recursively traverse sub-folders.
